facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 3, 1963, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 46 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 3, 1963, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 46 of 1962.

facts.text: The appellant Jabar Singh and the respondent Genda Lal, besides five others, contested the election to the Madhya Pradesh Assembly on behalf of the Morena Constituency No. 5.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Jabar Singh and the respondent Genda Lal, besides five others, had contested the election to the Madhya Pradesh Assembly on behalf of the Morena Constituency No. 5.

facts.text: This election took place on the 21st February, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: This election took place on the 21st February, 1962. In due course, the scrutiny of recorded votes took place and counting followed on the 27th February, 1962.

facts.text: Scrutiny of recorded votes took place and counting followed on the 27th February, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: In due course, the scrutiny of recorded votes took place and counting followed on the 27th February, 1962. As a result of the counting, the appellant was shown to have secured 5,671 votes, whereas the respondent 5,703 votes.

facts.text: As a result of the counting, the appellant was shown to have secured 5,671 votes, whereas the respondent 5,703 votes.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the counting, the appellant was shown to have secured 5,671 votes, whereas the respondent 5,703 votes. It is not necessary to refer to the votes secured by the other candidates.

facts.text: The appellant applied for recounting of the votes and thereupon, recounting followed as a result of which the appellant was declared elected having defeated the respondent by 2 votes.

anchor.surface_text: After the result of the counting was thus ascertained, the appellant applied for recounting of the votes and thereupon, recounting followed as a result of which the appellant was declared elected having defeated the respondent by 2 votes.

facts.text: The recounting showed that the appellant secured 5,656 votes and the respondent 5,654.

anchor.surface_text: The recounting showed that the appellant secured 5,656 votes and the respondent 5,654. Thereafter, the respondent filed an election petition from which the present appeal arises.

facts.text: Thereafter, the respondent filed an election petition from which the present appeal arises.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the respondent filed an election petition from which the present appeal arises. By his petition the respondent challenged the validity of the appellants election on the ground of improper reception of votes in favour of the appellant and improper rejection of votes in regard to himself.

facts.text: The Election Tribunal found that 10 ballot papers in favour of the respondent had been improperly rejected and 4 had been improperly accepted in favour of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal found that 10 ballot papers in favour of the respondent had been improperly rejected and 4 had been improperly accepted in favour of the appellant. That led to a difference of 12 votes and the position of the votes was found to be the respondent 5,664 and the appellant 5,652 votes.

facts.text: That led to a difference of 12 votes and the position of the votes was found to be the respondent 5,664 and the appellant 5,652 votes.

anchor.surface_text: That led to a difference of 12 votes and the position of the votes was found to be the respondent 5,664 and the appellant 5,652 votes. At this stage, the appellant urged before the Tribunal that there had been improper rejection of his votes and improper acceptance of the votes of the respondent,

facts.text: The Tribunal re-examined the ballot papers of the respondent as well as the appellant and came to the conclusion that 22 ballot papers cast in favour of the respondent had been wrongly accepted.

anchor.surface_text: so, he re- examined the ballot papers of the respondent as well as the appellant and came to the conclusion that 22 ballot papers cast in favour of the respondent had been wrongly accepted. The result was that the respondent had, in fact, not secured a majority of votes.

facts.text: As a consequence of these findings, the Tribunal declared that the election of the appellant was void and refused to grant a declaration to the respondent that he had been duly elected.

anchor.surface_text: As a consequence of these findings, the Tribunal declared that the election of the appellant was void and refused to grant a declaration to the respondent that he had been duly elected. This decision led to two cross-appeals before the High Court of Madhya Pradesh,

facts.text: This decision led to two cross-appeals before the High Court of Madhya Pradesh, No. 46 of 1962 and No. 1 of 1963 respectively.

anchor.surface_text: This decision led to two cross-appeals before the High Court of Madhya Pradesh, No. 46 of 1962 and No. 1 of 1963 respectively. The appellant challenged the conclusion of the Tribunal that his election was void, whereas the respon- dent disputed the correctness of the decision of the Tribunal that no declaration could be granted in his favour that be had been duly elected.

facts.text: In these appeals the High Court dismissed both the appeals and confirmed the decision of the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, both the appeals were dismissed and the decision of the Tribunal was confirmed. Against this decision, the appellant has come to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: Against this decision, the appellant has come to this Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision, the appellant has come to this Court by special leave. Later on, the respondent filed an application for leave to appeal to this Court, but the said application was filed beyond time.

facts.text: The respondent filed an application for leave to appeal to this Court, but the said application was filed beyond time. When the said application came on for hearing before this Court, the delay made by the respondent in preferring his application for special leave was not condoned.

anchor.surface_text: Later on, the respondent filed an application for leave to appeal to this Court, but the said application was filed beyond time. When the said application came on for hearing before this Court, the delay made by the respondent in preferring his application for special leave was not condoned, and so, the decision of the High Court against the respondent has become final and is no  1  15 E.L.R. 219.

facts.text: The Judgment was delivered on December 20, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: December 20, 1963. The Judgment of P. B. Gajendragadkar, A. Sarkar, K. N. Wanchoo and K. C. Das Gupta, JJ. was delivered by Gajendragadkar J. N. Rajagopala Ayyangar J. delivered a separate opinion.

facts.text: The polling for the election took place on February 21, 1962 and there were as many as seven candidates who participated in that poll.

anchor.surface_text: The polling for the election took place on February 21, 1962 and there were as many as seven candidates who participated in that poll. The appeal is, however, concerned only with two of them-Genda Lal and Jabar Singh-the latter being the returned candidate and is the appellant before us.

facts.text: On the first count of the ballot papers the Returning Officer computed the valid votes obtained by Genda Lal as 5,703 as against 5,671 which had been counted in favour of Jabar Singh.

anchor.surface_text: On the first count of the ballot papers the Returning Officer computed the valid votes obtained by Genda Lal as 5,703 as against 5,671 which had been counted in favour of Jabar Singh. Jabar Singh, however, immediately applied for a recount under rule 63 of the Rules on the ground that the original scrutiny and counting were defective

facts.text: Jabar Singh applied for a recount under rule 63 of the Rules on the ground that the original scrutiny and counting were defective and this was acceded to by the Returning Officer who carried out a recount.

anchor.surface_text: Jabar Singh, however, immediately applied for a recount under rule 63 of the Rules on the ground that the original scrutiny and counting were defective and this, though opposed, was acceded to by the Returning Office r who carried out a recount.

issues.text: The question of law which this appeal has raised for our decision is in relation to the nature and scope of the enquiry contemplated by sections 97, 100 and 101 of the Representation of People Act, 1951

anchor.surface_text: GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-The question of law which this appeal has raised for our decision is in relation to the nature and scope of the enquiry contemplated by sections 97, 100 and 101 of the Representation of People Act, 1951  No. 43 of 1951   hereinafter called the Act .

holdings.text: The scope of the enquiry under section 100(1)(d)(iii) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 is limited to determining whether the result of the election, insofar as it concerns the returned candidate, has been materially affected by the improper reception, refusal or rejection of any vote.

anchor.surface_text: what the Tribunal has to find is whether or not the election in so far as it concerns the returned candidate has been materially affected, and that means that the only point which the Tribunal has to decide is has the election of the returned

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.100(1)(d)(iii) requires proof of material effect on returned candidate's election; onus on petitioner limits scope; no broader scrutiny permitted without recrimination.

holdings.text: Section 97 applies when an election petition claims a declaration under section 101 that the petitioner or another candidate has been duly elected, requiring the returned candidate to recriminate by notice and security to challenge the alternative candidate's votes.

anchor.surface_text: Section 97 provides When in an election petition a declaration that any candidate other than the returned candidate has been duly elected is claimed, the returned candidate or any other party may give evidence to prove that the election of such

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions of s.97 proviso mandate procedure for counter-claim; failure precludes attack on petitioner's claim under s.101.

holdings.text: Without recrimination under section 97, the Tribunal under section 101(a) must presume the validity of counted votes under Rule 57(1) of the Conduct of Election Rules and cannot order full scrutiny of all votes.

anchor.surface_text: It is urged by Mr. Kapoor that the Tribunal cannot make a finding that the alternative candidate has in fact received a majority of the valid votes unless all the votes cast at the election are scrutinised and counted. In our opinion,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prima facie presumption from r.57(1) and s.36(8); recrimination required to dispute other votes; rejects full recount argument.

holdings.text: The returned candidate cannot, without recrimination under section 97, assail the validity of votes cast in favour of the petitioner or claim improper rejection of his own votes beyond defensive pleas under section 100(1)(d)(iii).

anchor.surface_text: If the returned candidate does not recriminate as required by s. 97, then he cannot make any attack against the alternative claim made by the petition. In such a case, an enquiry would be held under s. 100 so far as the validity

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defensive pleas only under s.100; offensive counter-claims require recrimination; harmonious construction avoids inconsistency.

holdings.text: The Election Tribunal erred in conducting a broad scrutiny of ballot papers for both candidates without recrimination, as the High Court correctly held.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore satisfied that the High Court was right in coming to the conclusion that the Tribunal was in error in holding that it was an authority charged with the duty of investigating the validity of votes for and

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of limited scope under ss.100/101; affirms High Court's reliance on Bhim Sen.

holdings.text: The view in Inayatullah Khan on the scope of enquiry under s.101(a) does not correctly represent the true legal position.

anchor.surface_text: We ought to add that the view taken by the Madhya Pradesh High Court in the case of Inayatullah Khan 1 in regard to the scope of the enquiry under s. 101 a does not correctly represent the true legal Position

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contradicts broader enquiry without recrimination; aligns with statutory scheme.

holdings.text: The construction of ss.100(1)(d)(iii) and 101 is substantially in accord with observations in Bhim Sen.

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion which we have reached in the present appeal is substantially in accord with the observations made by this Court in the case of Bhim Sen 3 though it appears that the points in question were not

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms prior Supreme Court observations as consistent.

holdings.text: The appeal is dismissed; no relief to respondent as his special leave application was dismissed for delay.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural finality; upholds void election declaration but denies seat claim.

holdings.text: Dissenting: Under s.100(1)(d)(iii), 'improper reception, refusal or rejection of any vote' permits returned candidate to prove improper acceptance of petitioner's votes or rejection of his own without recrimination, to show no material effect.

anchor.surface_text: The short question arising for consideration in this appeal may be stated thus In the context of the provisions contained in s. 100 1 d which permits an election of a returned candidate to be set, aside only

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive and textual reading allows defensive proof of majority valid votes; harmonises with s.101; rejects narrow limit to returned candidate's votes only.

Diwanchand Mahajan and Ors.  1 ., as well as the decision of this Court in Bhim Sen Gopali and Ors.  2  and held that the grievance made by both the parties in their respective appeals was not well- founded and that the decision of the Tribunal was right. In the result, both the appeals were dismissed and the decision of the Tribunal was confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, the view taken by the Allahabad Court in Lakshmi Shankar Yadav v. Kunwar Sripal Singh and Ors.  2 , cannot be said to interpret correctly the scope of the enquiry either under s. 100 or s. 101. The conclusion which we have reached in the present appeal is substantially in accord with the observations made by this Court in the case of Bhim Sen 3

anchor.surface_text: In Vashist Narain Sharma v. Dev Chandra and Ors.  2 , this Court has held that s. 100 1  c , as it then stood, places a burden on the objector to substantiate the objection that the result of the election has been materially affected by the improper acceptance or rejection of the nomination paper.

precedents.cited_proposition: burden on the objector to prove material effect from improper acceptance or rejection of nomination paper under s.100(1)(c)
precedents.cited_holding: where margin greater than rejected votes, result not affected

precedents.citation: Hari Vishnu Kamath v. Syed Ahmed Ishaque and others 1

anchor.surface_text: In Hari Vishnu Kamath v. Syed Ahmed Ishaque and others 1 , adverting to the expression the result of the election in s. 100 1  c , this Court stated that unless there is something in the context compelling a different interpretation, the said expression must be construed in the same sense as in section 66, and there it clearly means the result on the basis of the valid votes.

precedents.case_name: Hari Vishnu Kamath v. Syed Ahmed Ishaque
precedents.cited_proposition: meaning of 'the result of the election' in s.100(1)(c) refers to result on basis of valid votes

precedents.citation: Keshav Laxman Borkar v. Dr. Devrao Laxman Anande 1

anchor.surface_text: In Keshav Laxman Borkar v. Dr. Devrao Laxman Anande 1  this Court has pointed out that the expression valid votes has nowhere been defined in the Act, but in ,the light of the provision of s. 3 6  8   of the Act read with rule 58, two things are clear, first that the candidates are validly nominated candidates whose nomination papers are accepted by the returning officer after scrutiny, and second that the provision of s. 58 provides that the ballot papers which are not rejected under r. 57 are deemed to be valid ballot papers and are to be counted as such.

precedents.case_name: Keshav Laxman Borkar v. Dr. Devrao Laxman Anande
precedents.cited_proposition: meaning of 'valid votes'; nominated candidates whose papers accepted; non-rejected ballot papers deemed valid

precedents.citation: Bhim Sen v. Gopali and Ors.  1

anchor.surface_text: though some observations in Bhim Sen v. Gopali and Ors.  1  would appear to favour the construction which my learned brethren have adopted.

precedents.cited_proposition: observations favouring narrow scope of enquiry under ss.100,101
